head.title: Palestinians Should Accept Israeli Settlers; Extending Rights

hedline.hl1: Palestinians Should Accept Israeli Settlers; Extending Rights

block.p: "Peace or Annexation?" by Anthony Lewis (column, Sept. 20) blurs an important distinction between Israeli settlement of the occupied territories and Israel's treatment of Palestinians within their borders.

"Peace or Annexation?" by Anthony Lewis (column, Sept. 20) blurs an important distinction between Israeli settlement of the occupied territories and Israel's treatment of Palestinians within their borders.

As a Jew, I have often felt despair, often bordering on disdain, of Israeli policy toward West Bank Palestinians. The mistreatment and denial of rights, including the right to vote, is as inexcusable under traditional laws of Judaism as under the principles of freedom and self-determination accepted by Western democracies.
This does not, however, imply that Israel has an obligation to return the West Bank and Gaza Strip, any more than the United States has an obligation to return Texas to Mexico.

You should encourage President Bush and the leadership of the Jewish community to agree on a policy of accepting the occupied territories as part of Israel and encouraging Israel to respect the civil liberties of, and extend the rights of citizenship to the Palestinians who are living within its borders. STEPHAN COTTON San Francisco, Sept. 20, 1991
